title: Linked Data: Now what?

author: Noshir Contractor, Robert R. McCormick School of Engineering and Applied Science, Northwestern University

segmentation: So our next speaker is you've been hearing about him today in the keynote, so not sure if you wish to come.
So I'm going to just do a continuation.
A little bit of some of the ideas that we talked about this morning.
In some ways, it's actually quite.

It's quite similar to the issues that I raised this morning, so obviously before you year others who may, or at least one other who may want to sort of dampen the enthusiasm around, I'm I'm at the stage where I'm new to this area.
I'm excited by up intrigued by it, so I'm certainly consider myself as a cheerleader for this, but it's a fairly ignorant cheerleader.
In terms of the details associated with the semantic Web.
I will for that matter, with the linked open data from my.
Standpoint, one of the reasons I got excited about this is I can take all network data and think of it as being represented in file triples.
So any kind of network data there is can be put into the subject object predicate form and had from that point of view.
To me it seems like a very compelling way to think about all the kinds of network data that we talked about this morning, so it's a common framework to MASH network data.
I can have somebody somebody Co authoring when someone I could say somebody citing someone.
I can take all of these different types of data.
I can say someone is a friend of someone and put them all into this one thing.
And so, in 2005, when I first began to think about some of these issues, I got very excited about it.
I was at the University of Illinois in Urbana Champaign.
I was had lab at the National Center for Supercomputing Applications.
I put all the data that we have in the some of you here for the demo this morning.
So the tobacco example that I gave and we had several such examples.
I took all the data that we had in SQL and put it into sparkle and put it into triple Store and then try to query it with sparkle and the performance was.
Absolutely atrocious.
Does that mean it was just unbelievable?
So?
So what are my program?
My programming team said now she told us to put this into the Triple Store, so it's there.
But for any of the stuff that we're doing, we're going to go back and do things in SQL.
So I had to believe them.
And now, of course, I'm told that that's no longer the case.
That things are much better with querying etc.
So this is one of the reasons why I'm now revisiting this issue and ready with lots of data to put into this place.

So the second thing we can do besides matching the data is of course querying the data and so from a social network standpoint I talked about this morning they're looking for structural signatures of various kinds, so you know a is friends with show me all cases, so this would be a query.

Show me all cases in the data where a is friends with B who is cited by C, who is an expert on X, and so once I'm able to do those kinds of queries then I can use those structural signatures to make recommendations, so I can recommend that a contact C because of...
So think of the reasons to do that.

So from a recommendation system again, yet there are performance challenges and even to this day I believe their performance challenges when you look at these complex structured query make these complex structural signature queries on datasets that have millions of nodes and several orders more of links amongst these kinds of nodes.
But it is a project that we are working on and Jim Hendler and myself and some others are working on some social network data that is taking exactly this issue into account.
And the third, of course, is sort of the reasoning example, and this is where things like I will come into the picture.
Verify SAFC is an expert on X&Y, is a subspecialty OC.
Then I can also assume I can infer from it that C is going to be an expert on Y and use that as a way of making these kinds of recommendations.
So what are the games for social network research?
Is a long list larger amounts of data higher resolution of data that is in terms.
We talked about the fact that links can have lots of degrees of richness in terms of what that link means.

Lanja tude no data an issue that I did not describe explicitly this morning, but the fact that you can have timestamp data, it makes it a very powerful obviously and then combine that with the matching querying and the reasoning issue.
So from a social network standpoint, I think this is fantastic.
I think that one of the questions that we were asked by Carlos is.
With social network data with social networks be better off without linked open data and the answer of course is absolutely not.
It said this has incredible potential of unleashing a whole new generation of network research of the kind that we have not been able.
To do so far.
What are the games for the Semantic web community?
Well, I think that being in making recommendations that are motivated more by social network theories rather than only my standard sort of line about this is.

And I'll say this in a friendly rejoinder to colleagues who are primarily in killer computer science is that if you look at all the recommendation systems that are out there, they made by smart people because computer scientists are smart people, but it's made it's made based on intuition for the most part you are looking at it and saying I think This is why I should make this recommendation.
It's a very reasonable way to do.
But it does not systematically take into account decades of social science research that tell us exactly why a particular link is more likely to be successful in the other.

So I think for the semantic web community in connecting with people who are studying social network theories will provide a lot of new insights into how to make these recommendations to be more effective than they are.

Likewise, the social, I think the semantic web community can also benefit from some of the social network methodologies that I developed this morning about be star or exponential random graph models, which is only one.
Family of network methods that have been developed lately but which are statistical based tools that can provide a lot more insight into what kinds of recommendations can be made in this community.
We talked about the identification of killer applications and again the last my last speaker out here.
Tom was saying that we should get.
For it is that right?
Yeah, so I'm not.
You know this is my untextured, untested conjecture about this issue I think, and again maybe controversial, maybe not.
I think exposing linked data has gone past the tipping point.
There's no doubt when you see those sequence of slides over a period of time to see what's happening.
I think that's a pretty well established, but I think where the applications that are using this link data.
That is where I see the tipping point being far from near this, we don't really have many good applications.
I would conjecture that Link data, wireless proliferating the killer application will require the addition of the social into the data.

Well, and by that I mean that in order for it to take off to see applications that might be more successful, we need to start including more of the social nodes into it so that it's not just data that is being linked to other data but also date some of those nodes need to be people and to use those as an example of moving things forward.

I also think that the design issues that have been raised before are crucial when I talk about this to most of my friends in social network analysis, they just they have a really tough time understanding it.
We have a very difficult time understanding what it means to link data.
What it means to do any of these issues.
And so I think that there are some just obvious basic obstacles that need to be overcome in this area.
I'll close by talking about the case of the pop side grid, so the pups about closer, close this slide.
This particular slide with that.
So the pop side grid is an effort from the National Cancer Institute to try to build some kind of linked open data structure of some kind within this community.
So the premise here is just like I talked this morning about the tobacco example.
The idea here was, is it possible?
It turns out that in this in these communities.
Take tobacco itself, for example, that the community has lots and lots of surveys and other sources of data related to tobacco research, so that's one example of population science.
But here is the dilemma.
They face these surveys that are conducted like the National Health Information Survey, for example in the US.

These are very complex surveys that have complex code books and is conducted periodically and all the data is stored in the National Center for Health Statistics and most population science researchers spend so much time learning how to use one of these datasets that then they spend their entire career just mining that one data set.
It takes too much effort on their part to go learn for different datasets, so the dream year is but many of these datasets because they contain many of the same variables.
The dream from the NCI stand from the National Cancer Institute standpoint is.
Show me a simple way in which I can query the web and say show me all datasets that have variable X and variable Y.

Bring those datasets to me and then allow me to do a correlation across of X&Y things like smoking prevalence and cancer, for example, show me those allow me to do this analysis across the data set so I don't need to know each data set.
I don't need to know the code books and how to extract that information from each data set.
A terrific idea that these that the population science community was really interested, and then of course the next stage was well, how do we start classifying these variables?
These variables are not exactly the same.
Immediate pushback in terms of the ontologies, right?
In terms of anything.
That said, I need to have definitions for these variables, etc.
This community could not agree on it and I'm this is not the first community that I've seen.

I think there are a lot of communities that really give push back because they feel that putting those kinds of categories, either privilege of particular perspective or create problems down the line for more innovation in this area when these things have to be changed.
Now I know that you're going to say that's not true.
We have lightweight ontologies.
We have different kinds of flexibility's.
But I'm not convinced that the community that you want to serve has bought into those arguments, so that's, um, that's a challenge that I think that we face out here.
What turned out to be more interesting was they said, yeah, it's useful to be able to look at these datasets, etc.
But what this is where the social comes into it?

They said, well, it would be really helpful if somebody who has worked in a data set I would like to know who that person is, so that when someone I'm looking at a variable, it should tell me not only which of the variables I want to look for, correlating it with, but show me other people who have used these in a certain workflow.
Show me other documents that are reporting the results from this particular up.

This particular variable show me other analytic tools that have been used, so once you start looking at it from a social standpoint where it's not just linking the data but linking the data analytic tools to workflows to people into concepts into documents that then got them much more excited.
So this is a project right now in progress.
This is the one that we are doing.
A proof of concept with Jim Hendler's group at RPI for the National Cancer Institute, so I think I'm going to go ahead and start with that, thanks.
Thank you.
